reviews.title_review: Great 1080p res in 6' display, awesome dslr camera, PC users must have it.
reviews.body: Its been a week since I have had it. Before this I had Galaxy Note II and this Nokia 1520 feels great. It's amazingly fast. The most valuable thing I found in this phone is the Camera. The camera has all the DSLR functions and it is 20 mp. The 1080p display with bright and brilliant picture is perfect to watch movies and videos. I wear jeans all the time and it fits fine in my front pockets.

reviews.name: Phuong Pham
reviews.title_review: The Lumia 1520 is a nice phone.
reviews.body: The Lumia 1520 is a nice phone... until you have a problem with it. The screen is more fragile than any other smartphone I have had and broke after just 35 days of owning the phone. After 30 days Microsfot would do nothing. Worse - what sellers dont tell you is that replacing the screen on one of these is about impossible, unlike most other phones. So if you use your phone in real life conditions that involve banging against stuff (not even dropping it)... STAY AWAY

reviews.name: Jewel
reviews.title_review: Received this phone within a day and by far the fastest phone I've own!
reviews.body: The best phone I ever own!!! My old phone went out and I received the phone the next day. My children loves the game apps.

reviews.name: Jimmie West
reviews.body: Does this phone is United States version

reviews.name: Mark Caldwell
reviews.title_review: Could be a great phone but...
reviews.body: All my smartphone experience has been with iphone since 3g. So about 4+ years of just using Apple. I got tired of the small screen and Apple's reluctance to really catch up to the other phones that have begun surpassing it. I knew there would be difficulties adjusting to a new style of phone, but I loved the screen and loved the idea of a high caliber phone camera (really getting into phone photography in the last few months), so I decided to go with the Lumia 1520. The screen is big and gorgeous. I feel the size of the phone is a great fit in my hand. The battery life is AMAZING. The camera is excellent BUT there are a few things that really temper my initial elation with this phone. The number one WORST thing about the phone is the freakin' touchscreen sensitivity. Even turned down from High to Normal it's TOO sensitive. I'm sure it is just a software issue that can fix it but for now it's just about a deal breaker for me and the number 1 reason I wouldn't recommend this phone to others. Multiple, multiple times during use I will accidentally launch apps or open links that I was just trying to scroll past. Sometimes just touching the screen, even without lifting your finger or doing any gestures will cause whatever you are touching to launch. So annoying! I have to leave an open space on the live tile screen so I can flick over to the app menu without launching whatever app is there. The other thing that happens frequently when scrolling thru an article is that it will highlight a whole swath of text when you try to flick up. It's instantaneous too. Not like you're holding your finger on the text and then swiping up. Using 2 fingers spaced apart to scroll seems to reduce the number of times this happens but it certainly does not eliminate it. Again, I'm sure this is a software issue that hasn't been updated from the small screen to a larger screen so touch is getting misinterpreted, but until this is remedied, I definitely would not tell any of my friends to get this phone. The other main con to this phone, and it's not the phone's fault, is the terrible apps. I don't understand why MS isn't full on supporting the app store with fantastic apps to rival anyone else. I didn't realize how big the gap was between Apple and MS as far as quality apps go. It is vast. So many apps seem unrefined, like "it's good enough". There have only been a few that look and feel extremely polished. Disappointing, to say the least. All that said, I will be keeping my phone since I do a lot of camera photography and video/web reading and the screen is better than anyone else for doing those things, with an incredible battery life. But until the touchscreen sensitivity issue is amended I do not recommend this phone to others.

reviews.name: Andrea H.
reviews.body: The item was in the condition described if not better. I am extremely pleased with my purchase. The product came in timely fashion.

reviews.name: Jesse
reviews.body: This phone suddenly ran low in power about 3 months after getting it. I could not get it to charge or turn back on. So I buy a new phone and then all of a sudden 3 months later I go to charge it and it works WTF! Spent 1000 dollars on the iPhone 6

reviews.name: ZT
reviews.title_review: An Overall Good Product With Minor Faluty Designs
reviews.body: I've been using iPhone for several years and have been thinking to try something new and looking for alternatives. When I saw this phone on sale, I bought it and also ordered a "3 Packs EnGive Nokia Lumia 1520 High Definition(HD) Screen Protector Flim Ultra Clear with Cleaning Cloth"  B00GBTNUKQ Pros: 1. One of the top hardware spec in the market , 6 inch FHD screen, powerful 4-core chips. This phone is much more powerful than nearly all other smartphones in the market, iphone 5s, Nexus 5, S4, etc. 2. Second the best smartphone camera in the market, next to the Lumia 1020, and this phone's camera reacts much faster than 1020, and it can save RAW format photo. 3. Free Office 365. 4. It has micro-SD card slot 5. The Nokia HereMap App and HereDrive can download maps (not only US but all countries) and this phone becomes a GPS even if you don't have data or signal! 6. The Nokia MixRadio (need wifi or data) is better than Apple's iRadio. 7. It has FM Radio function, but requires a headset to work. Cons: 1. The usability is bad! The system design do not effectively utilize the amazing 6 inch screen, the keyboard always occupy about 2/3 of the screen. Win 8 system setting is not as easy and simply as IOS: in IOS you can easily scroll the menu on the left and browse and select information on the right, in Win 8 you need to click into one and another manual options then exit and select another, and there are too many options. 2. There's only AT&T version in U.S, the AT&T remove the Qi Wireless charging function. 3. US Version does not come with headset (if you want to use the FM radio function, you need use your own headset) 4. The phone I have is extremely hot, not only when I play games, but also when I take pictures. The high temperature area is the corner on the right side of the camera (when you face the camera) 5. The screen of my phone has a minor color unbalance issue, about 1/3 of the screen close to the Win key has a yellow tint issue. Overall it is a good phone, and excellent phablet. It has wonderful hardware, but still has some design issue. Whether to buy it depends on your needs. There are other cool-looking phones in the market, such as MOTO X with customized color, iPhone 5s and 5c. There are some high-value hardware phones such as Nexus 5, which is fully unlocked with awesome hardware for only $350. To be honest, this phone is neither cool-looking (imagine when you hold such a huge thing to make phone call) nor very good "bang for the buck", but it is no double one of the two best phone-tablet so far. The other one is Note 3, which seems to have a more mature OS and better utilization of stylus pen, but the Lumia 1520 has a better camera. Overall, 3.5 stars.

reviews.name: Ibuystuffhere
reviews.body: After spending more time with this phone I take it all back. Even though it is aging and not as up with tech as newer phones...it was THE best phone I ever owned. It saddens me that my first review was done in such anger and ticked off-ness. It also saddens me that in April 2015 I dropped this phone (as I had done many times since getting it) and broke the digitizer causing the touch to not work right and had to replace it with a Galaxy S6. Now I really know which phone is the "Worst Phone Ever" I miss my Lumia 1520 so much that I barely use My GS6.

reviews.name: Laura R.
reviews.body: Love the live tiles and the big screen

reviews.name: Leo James
reviews.body: It was a good phone, but windows phone is dying. So please don't get this phone, and get the much better Nexus 6P.

reviews.name: Jeffrey D Boyle
reviews.title_review: Don't buy this phone. Stress Cracks the Screen
reviews.body: Don't buy this phone. My wife bought this phone and loved it...until the screen cracked. She did not drop it, kept it in a case, and carried it in her purse.. When she did some investigation, she discovered that this is quite a common problem. Many of these model phones are suffering from stress cracks caused by the thin case flexing and damaging the screen. So far Nokia has not stepped up to take care of their customers, so we are left in the position of paying a deductible on our damage insurance to get the phone replaced. With no guarantee the next one won't do the same thing.

reviews.name: Andrew
reviews.body: If only you could edit a email you want to forward, this would be a great phone (Actually, I found out its not just this phone but all Windows phones). It's crazy but if you want to forward an email to someone and take something out of the forwarded email, lets say "bad language" you can't do so. This is a basic need when forwarding confidential info as well.

reviews.name: AbdominalSnowman
reviews.body: If you are new to the windows phone franchise, DO NOT BUY THIS PHONE. I have had mine for almost a year now and sometimes I just want to throw I at a wall. Microsoft did not pay attention to all of the little details about this phone making it damn annoying to use. If I could chose again, I would choose an iPhone, simply because it works properly.

reviews.name: Spider
reviews.title_review: Made the switch from iphone easily
reviews.body: I like it. It is big but I work outside and don't carry a phone while working so its great in the truck when I have down time. There's a couple pipe fitting apps I couldn't get on it that are available only througha apple. Its fast and the camera is awesome as is the screen. Switching from iPhone was easier than I expected. I'm no tech wizard be any means but I was able to handle the task in a few hrs. Good overal experience and the only reason for 4 stars was due to lack of apps and there's a few annoying update pop ups Update. You will not be able to access drop screen menus, very annoying. Ie. When you hover the cursor over an option and a screen comes down with other options, this does not work in wp8. I tried everything to contact a human about this issue with no luck. Tried to contact someone on line, no luck. So customer support is the exact opposite of apple where you can talk to an American in country about issues and get some sort of resolve. There is no forward button. You will not be able to use google chrome. You can set your browser to google but your internet shortcut button is defaulted to Bing rendering that button useless unless you like Bing. I do not. I cannot access my podcast that I listen to on my daily commute through network alone. Says I need wi-fi. Never had this issue with iPhone. I am keeping my iPhone to use as iPod so I can overcome this problem and still have my pipe fitting apps. I am keeping my 1520 because of the awesome screen and all and all i do like it slightly better than iPhone for my use as a tablet. Hulu is great and the streaming has been flawless with 1-2 bar 4g service. I just hope they get some updates to fix these simple issues that apple and Android have overcome years ago. My wife is not so happy with the 1020 for the reasons mentioned above. She could be going back to apple but she likes the 41mp camera over the 8mp camera on the iPhone 5. Update, if you had an iPhone the iPhone will steal all your text messages from people with iphones and you will not get them unless you sign out of apple and turn your imessage off on your old phone. I did this and it worked fine, my wife has been on the phone for two days (6hrs) and she still cannot receive messages from anyone with an iPhone. She is less than happy. YouTube is not very easy to use either, it makes you watch full length ads and you can't get to the content. Basically rendering YouTube useless for videos over a minute long. Update AT&T is an awful company to do business with. Go with Verizon and maybe have a little better luck. I'm keeping my phone because were stuck with att for two more years. We will be switching after that. You will not be able to receive iPhone text. Apple blames it on att, att blames it on apple. I got my phone on line just before they changed ios7 my wife got on a week later after changes were made and she's not able to receive iPhone text.They told her to contact all her iPhone contacts and tell them to delete then add her as a contact again, not something you want to do with your business contacts. I know hers is a 1020 but the OS is the same. Its a windowsphone vs iPhone thing and we are the ones that pay. The 1520 is a good phone but obviously there's some serious issues.

reviews.name: brittany
reviews.body: I HATE IT!! I mean yea its nice in look and the screen is big but if you want a phone that messes up constantly then this is the phone for you. AND im on the next program so I can't get a different phone. All they do is send me another Nokia Lumia 1520 which does the same thing! It'll randomly open up app which then the screen and home/back button wont work unless I hit the lock button then I can exit. Then the screen will constantly jump so then I cant do anything on it. Or ill be texting and it'll type a whole bunch of different letters by itself. Yea. DO NOT GET THIS!!!!!!!!!

reviews.name: Gengol
reviews.title_review: After the Windows Phone 8.1 update came out, ruined Bluetooth Voice Navigation
reviews.body: The voice navigation of the "Nokia Drive+" was perfectly working through Bluetooth when the OS was still Windows Phone 8.0 but after the update Windows Phone 8.1, the voice navigation through bluetooth disappeared. The music & video audio through bluetooth is fine, what I need is the Voice Audio that is working with "Nokia Drive+" navigation app that is when connected through bluetooth on my car radio disappeared after applying the Windows Phone 8.1 update. Its working fine using the audio jack on the phone but it beats the purpose of having a bluetooth radio and cellphone. I hate this 8.1 update, everything was working fine on 8.0, I wish i did NOT update this once a beautiful phone. Microsoft you ruined everything once more! THANKS FOR NOTHING!

reviews.name: Matt
reviews.body: You can get a list of all the awesomeness that's the phone and display from other reviews. My serious gripe is the quality of applications. They're terrible! I ditched my iPhone 5 for this. The first thing I did was download the Amazon Kindle reader. This is big enough to be a good light weight reader. It's a D- grade application. The iOS version is A+, so why is it so bad for the Windows Phone? Amazon just threw out a crappy app to shut Win phone users up. No other reason. The app crashes all the time, you have to reinstall, download the books, 75% of books won't download, and only 10% of features that other quality apps have. I blame Microsoft for this. Did they think that developers would just come running to build quality apps? Do you think Apple just sat back and did nothing? No way! They went out and ensured that there would be quality apps for their products. Granted, there are some quality apps like Office, but from other developers this is an epic failure. Microsoft should have done more. All I'd like to do now it take it back.

reviews.name: SA
reviews.body: I am must say I didn't buy this phone from Amazon. I bought this phone from Microsoft online store. I had it for a day before I returned it. this was my worse buying experience from any where. I was sprint customer for long time. I decided to move to AT&T because of this phone. Microsoft sold me this phone for $200 with 450 minutes for $39.98 and 3GB of data for $20.. I receive phone activation email with contact number. when I called the number they told me they can not help me and I have to call Microsoft number so I called them and they told me they cannot activate the phone and I should call AT&T. I called AT&T they moved my number. I asked what kind of plan I got the rep told me 450 minutes and 3Gb of data. I tried to use my data after I left home but it didn't work. I called AT&T and they told me there is no data plan on my account. if I want 3GB I have to pay $30 they don't care what Microsoft sold me because only AT&T can say how much it cost. I had to cancel my service and return the phone. I don't have a cell phone service for 3 days now.

title_item: Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 7.0 3G T211 8GB-Black unlocked phone

reviews.name: Bola Radeyo
reviews.title_review: I bought them for my nieces because they are good. You use it as in Africa
reviews.body: I bought one then bought another two. I bought them for my nieces because they are good. You use it as in Africa, Europe, Mexico, Poland. Good product.

reviews.name: Daisy S
reviews.title_review: What a wonderful combo PHONE and TABLET works wonderfully as a LARGE phone and as mini tablet! A detailed review!
reviews.body: Just to let you know, I bought this tablet phone combo in White on Amazon as it was just what I was searching for as it is a tablet and an 100 percent GSM UNLOCKED phone! I have used and tested thoroughly and found that it does have so many overall advantages. So as a techie, I tested this phone/tablet out to great lengths and below I will list what I have found to be the Pros and Cons of this amazing device. *This is a excellent choice in an ALL IN ONE device. For me, I use it as my primary phone with no contract plan that includes minutes and a small data plan. (Most of the time, I am on WiFi for the internet but I need my minutes to make and receive phone calls etc). Also I want to state that the phone accepts a MICRO Sim card, not a regular full sized Sim. Since I had an old Samsung Tab 2 3g with a regular Sim, I just removed my old Sim Card from the older tablet phone and cut the Sim with a Micro Sim cutter, placed it into my Tab 3 phone/tablet and my data was there, my minutes were there, worked great! Also this tablet installed an update to the OS from December 2013 and this tablet phone runs so fast now! If you are looking for: a lightweight combo phone and tablet that is very easy to hold in one hand comfortably and you want a basic and easy to use tablet, then consider this tablet. While it does not have every bell and whistle installed on it, it is a good choice for: Checking emails, Getting Online, Looking at Pictures, Watching Home Movies. And as a bonus, if you request it, I will share with you how to get Archived Flash so you can watch online videos on the tablet. And I encourage you to ask me questions in the comments (should you have a question) about this tablet and I will answer all questions. Here are the Pros and the Cons below. PROS: 1- WiFi connects easily and the signal is good in most places I tested. And I received a STRONG WiFi signal on this device. 2- The advantage of having a SD card slot that will hold up to 64GB. 3- Small and lightweight. Comfortable to carry around and place in backpack or briefcase easily. 4- Micro USB Port - This is common in most tablets these days, but the older Tab 2 line did not have micro port but the propriety wider port. 5- Screen clarity - For me, I found this screen easy to read eBooks on and view internet pages. 6- I had a Tab 3 7.0 WiFi only and sold it to a friend, bought this one and find that it is a much better tablet. CONS: - Low internal storage - this tablet comes with 8GB internal storage (advertised). Because the OS takes up room, apps etc, take up room, the tablet just has about 4.7GB in the internal storage. This is not good because when you install an app from the Playstore, it goes onto your internal storage not on the External SD card. (The external SD card is meant for personal files such as your music, photos, home movies,etc). **The GOOD NEWS IS: If you do not install a lot of huge games onto this tablet, you will probably do just fine with this storage. - Heat – Under normal conditions (when not running intense games or downloading files etc), this tablet runs very cool. It did get up to 102 degrees ONCE when I downloaded lots of apps from the Playstore, but then it went back to a low 80 degrees after that. This is normal though for this particular tablet, not a cause for any alarm. Bottom line and Summary: Would I buy this phone tablet all over again? Yes in a heartbeat! If you are looking to buy a LARGE PHONE that you can use as a MINI TABLET, this is the one that I recommend to you as I love mine! Since I am a techie, you can ask me any questions in the comments under this review.

title_item: Samsung SM-G730V Galaxy S III Mini Verizon Phone [?]

reviews.body: This phone was like new. It looked like a new phone and works like a new one, including great battery life.

reviews.name: amanda c andrews
reviews.title_review: Got phone yesterday all is good so far but only problem i can see is ...
reviews.body: Got phone yesterday all is good so far but only problem i can see is that the charging cable that came w the phone literally came apart in my hands this morning, leaving the metal piece in the phone! Got it out and replaced the cable so hopefully the hubby will be pleased now!

reviews.name: Shannon Holder
reviews.body: Operating system is a little slow at times and cannot run several programs at once without locking up.

title_item: Motorola Moto E (Verizon LTE Prepaid)

reviews.name: J
reviews.title_review: A capable smartphone for less than $50. It is legit.
reviews.body: At less than $50, this is value. It will access LTE data, get you around the web, provide Google's voice-prompted turn-by-turn navigation, YouTube, the voice-recognition capability of Google Now, and speak-to-type. Its specs aren't premium, but you're paying less than $50 and getting a reliable old Chevy truck that won't die, that will get you out of Dodge when the zombie apocalypse comes, will start when you need it, get you through a blizzard to the grocery store or hospital. No, this isn't the status symbol see-and-be-seen luxury ride. If you want that, then pay 10 to 20 times more. Yes, 10 to 20 times more. A Nexus 6 is $549. An iPhone 6S Plus 128GB is $949 before tax. So, no, it's not a badass Secret Service-looking black Suburban, a Hummer, a Range Rover, or Porsche Cayenne, but it will get you to the same places. It is an entry-level Android and a full-on smartphone without qualification quotes. By 2015 standards, Motorola has provided a solidly functional and capable device that will perform what a smartphone should be able to perform in 2015. This is a smartphone, no doubt about it. This is perfect for a backup phone if you're between premium phones - say, selling one top of the line phone while waiting for the release date of the next latest and greatest.

reviews.name: Hans K.
reviews.body: Great "entry level" phone. I use quotes because to be flat out honest, this is pretty much everything most people need in a phone. Yes, there are some folks out there who need to have the latest and greatest devices, but this one probably takes care of most 80% of smartphone users out there. The finish and backing on the phone are made out of great materials. The backing is a slight rubberized material and doesn't slide off tables or in your hand. My friend has a Motorola Nexus 6 phone which is several hundreds more than this one, and the phone is pretty similar in build and finish. The Verizon model of this phone, in particular, is great because there are some simple workarounds for those who are computer/tech savvy to get the GSM slot of this phone unlocked for use on ATT and T-Mobile. Do a quick google search on "Moto E Verizon GSM unlock" and that should get you started. I struggled with it a little bit, but after about 30 minutes I was able to get it unlocked and used it with Cricket Wireless. 4G LTE data was occasionally inconsistent, however. Overall a great device with screen size and form similar to that of an iPhone 5. One frustrating thing about later versions of Android is the inability for apps to read/write on to your SD card (since Kitkat, I believe). I frequently listen to podcasts using the BeyondPod app, which downloads MP3s directly to the phone now, instead of on my SD card, because of the limitations on the Android OS. Still a great phone at a tremendous value, if you can get these during occasional sales at around $40.

reviews.name: Quin Davis
reviews.body: Two small things about this phone. Two things that drive me crazy. 1.) NFL mobile. SERIOUSLY? Not everyone wants to watch an overglorifed game of fetch. (To put it short,bloatware.) 2.) I bought this to use on wifi. Either I have the sim card in,and it trys to activate the phone EVERY time i turn on the phone. OR i take the sim card out,and have a lovely "no sim found" notification at ALL times. BUT. It is a beautiful phone with little to dislike about it. Good camera,good screen,nice sounding speaker (despite it only being mono) and above all,an amazing deal. Would recommend to anyone who needs a small & cheap smartphone with moderate hardware. *4 month update* This phone is still amazing. both of my complaints i had with this phone have now been fixed. 1) NFL mobile can be disabled in the app settings,which removes it entirely from the app menu. 2)If the sim is in,it will try to activate your phone. BUT. if you turn the phone off and on 3 or so times,it stops trying and goes away completely. HOWEVER...This phone is running the Android 5.1.....if you don't know why this is a bad thing,let me explain: Android 5.1 has an issue with ram leaking... (This means your ram gets eaten up quickly and can only be fixed by restarting the phone.) If you don't restart this phone every couple days,it gets very slow. this problem would be fixed if they updated the phones firmware to android 5.1.1 or android 6.0,but unfortunately there is no update as of today. (04.22.16)

reviews.name: A. Raccoon
reviews.body: I love this phone. For the price it is amazing. The screen is sharp and clear, the interface is responsive, the sound quality is decent, and the buttons are unobtrusive yet responsive. The back camera is decent enough for general purpose. The front camera is meh at best, but I'm not a fan of selfies and it works well enough for Skype. I have been having occasional issues with the WiFi randomly cutting out for seemingly no reason, but that's pretty much my only complaint. If you want a solid smart-phone without dropping 500 dollars for a hundred features you'll never use, while still having what you need (and more), this is the smart-phone for you.

reviews.name: vinyldoc
reviews.title_review: Awesome out of the box with PagePlus sim card!
reviews.body: Right out of the box, I put in my PagePlus Sim Card from my old Droid Razr and then turned it on, as recommended in a review. It automatically connected with the Verizon network and my local wifi! It asked for my Google acct and it put in all my contacts and calendar and apps. I just called my dad and he said it sounded great. I haven't tried the Bluetooth yet, so will report on that later. For a $46 phone and $33 a month for PagePlus, it's awesome. And this is from somebody with nothing but desktop and laptop Macs who had the first generation iPhone for 7 years.

reviews.name: Zachari Clark
reviews.title_review: Decent phone. Great for the price but you can do a lot better if you have the money
reviews.body: This phone is great performance-wise. It functions faster than the Moto G which I am upgrading from. The graphics are great. The snappy response with most apps is great. Only a couple drawbacks. It has NO flash. Kind of a bummer cause that would improve the camera quality marginally. It has no notification LED. That was one of the biggest things I loved about the Moto G. I didn't have to turn it on to see if I had something waiting for me. I could just glance at it and be done. The signal is weaker now that I'm using this phone. I don't know whether that's due to the phone itself or my network area. I've tried resolving this issue multiple times but keep losing signal (ironic....). Overall a fantastic deal for the price. It runs wonderfully. A little bummed out I can't root it but that's kinda expected with something locked down to a prepaid plan such as this.

reviews.name: Andrew Hendershot
reviews.body: As long as you take the sim card out of the phone before you turn it on the first time you can actually use it with a post paid plan. Works great with my post paid Verizon lte plan. Great phone overall, rarely lagging and handling most things just fine. I will definitely get the third gen moto e when it is released. UPDATE July 1st 2016: I have been happily using this phone as my daily driver for the past few months and it has been amazing for the price. Even though it is still running lollipop, most apps and software are still supported on the phone. There are also a few lag spikes every now and then on the phone but not too often. My opinion has still not changed about this phone and I will use it for as long as I can.

reviews.name: Scott (Technogeek)
reviews.body: This is an amazing phone for the price, uses a modern version of the Android OS, and is fast enough for everything I have thrown at it with its quad processor. The screen is clear and bright, and it has a micro SD card slot to expand its small internal memory. The call quality is as good as my Samsung Note 5, and the speakerphone is reasonably loud. The WiFi connects instantly, the Bluetooth works great, and the battery lasts all day. It just works, and works well. It also comes with a blue case for bump protection and a wall ac charger. Recommended

reviews.name: Nurse Debi
reviews.body: Reliable and has all the bells and whistles I like. It has a small memory, which is unfortunate. It arrived with so many apps I won't ever use and can't remove, but I installed an SD card, which has helped immensely. The cover is non-slip providing a good grip. The battery lasts a long time. The camera is so-so and I find it difficult to access the options, but I can grab a quick picture when the need arises. With Verizon pre-paid plan, I have unlimited calls and text and a fair amount of data, with the option to purchase more. $45 month with automatic debit. Why would I want a contract for three times the price?

reviews.name: Robin M.
reviews.title_review: Very Nice Simple Phone that Works Well
reviews.body: Nice smallish phone that works very well for an inexpensive price. Motorola is known for producing phones that interface very well with network phone service, data, WiFi, Bluetooth, etc. This little Moto E is no exception. I bought it to use as a source of WiFi data reception for my Garmin RV760 GPS, which will not maintain a Bluetooth connection with my Samsung Galaxy. This inexpensive phone serves that purpose extremely well, and you do not have to activate it to use it with WiFi, Bluetooth, etc.

reviews.name: Eevee Christy
reviews.body: I got this phone as a bridge phone until I could upgrade my contract phone. I'm not a phone wiz or super techy, so I can't tell you how well the system works or any of that jazz. I can only tell you what happened to me. If all you're using this phone for is texting, calling, and clash of clans - get it. Other than that, it's a little on the slow side and it doesn't run as smoothly as a Samsung or iPhone. I have had both. It can crash sometimes because the system is slow, but the battery life is great and it's fairly easy on my data plan. I maintained pretty well off of 3-5 gigs a month. It's pretty cheap too. I'd say it's perfect for someone who doesn't really use their phone that much.

reviews.name: KarissaJae
reviews.title_review: One step up from a flip phone...this is the one! :)
reviews.body: If your goal is a super cheap phone, that runs well, has some strength, that you can call or text on...buy this phone. Super cheap! It has no space, so don't try to download any apps, just take a few pics. I bought it for my 10 yo to use at a camp, for one week. She thought she was something else, and it held up nicely. Use it for one ounce of an upgrade over a flip phone...for this price, who cares. It serves it's purpose. Understanding all that, buy it if is fits your needs!

reviews.name: g graham
reviews.body: I bought this phone in march 2016 for $46 and just now made it a tracfone. You have to pay verizon for 1 month of prepaid service to unlock it. Not a bad unlocking policy. I paid $34 which includes taxes. So for $80 i have a new tracfone which is a very economical service since i make few phone calls. I also have a free google voice number and make free calls/texts over wifi through the hangouts app. I've had 3 Motorola phones and like them very well. Pure Android experience without altering the interface.

reviews.name: Victor Blake
reviews.title_review: Great deal for a new Android phone
reviews.body: Nice phone. Just to correct one previous review. If you purchase this as a replacement VZW phone, you must use it as a prepaid phone for at least one month (30 days) at a cost of $30+ taxes. After that you can convert it to a bring your own device to move to your VZW account to replace a device on an existing line or for add a line. Even with the +$30 this is a great deal for a great phone. Substantively the same as the Moto X, a bit larger, but not by much. Has a different size SIM card (larger) than the Moto X. Still a great phone.

reviews.name: Kevin K
reviews.title_review: It activated fine with my existing prepaid Verizon SIM
reviews.body: Hard to review a phone I buy as a spare in case I accidentally break the iPhone I'm currently using. It activated fine with my existing prepaid Verizon SIM. I was able to download old apps I've had on previous Android phones. Size felt comfortable. I've learned that it won't be upgraded to Marshmallow. 5GB of builtin storage is small. So I inserted an inexpensive 32GB microSD card. The advantage of the Android ecosystem is that many of the phones support SD cards. So I can buy a $11 card and upgrade by 32GB. Vs Apple. The downside is many apps won't support going onto the SD card. You have to manage it that way.

reviews.name: Andie
reviews.body: I'm pretty pleased with this phone so far. I think I've had it for about a year now. I love Android, and it hasn't given me many issues. The only thing I've noticed is that every now and then it starts running very slowly, and If you try to force it, it'll freeze for a moment, and then close out of whatever you were trying to do. That can be frustrating, but it only lasts for a moment, and then it is normal again. Frankly I think that's a pretty small issue, especially for the price and user-friendliness of this phone.

reviews.name: Tjamie
reviews.body: I love this phone. It is very durable, user friendly and reliable. Of course the service reliability comes from the service provider, Verizon. Sometimes now, since I have had the phone a while it will freeze up and give me some problems with slowing down and not being as sensitive to touch on the touch screen as it used to be. The little plastic lining that goes around the phone comes off really easy, with almost any knock, I am actually surprised I have not lost mine already. overall, it is an excellent phone.

reviews.name: Computer Dev
reviews.title_review: Great, cheap phone for casual users! Works on T-Mobile. Good performance and durability.
reviews.body: WHY I GOT IT: I used to have a Samsung S4, but I decided to get this phone because it had the Lollipop OS, and my S4 was getting slow. I have T-Mobile and was able to easily get my SIM card working on this phone. USING T-MOBILE ON THIS PHONE: Disclaimer: I am an Android developer so perhaps, the steps were easier for me than for an average person, but it's pretty much copy and paste to get this phone working with T-Mobile. I used this link to get it working : http://forum.xda-developers.com/moto-e-2015/general/how-to-verizon-moto-e-2015-gsm-network-t3098953 PERFORMANCE I really like this phone and was surprised at its performance for such a low price point. It's actually faster than my S4. "Ok Google" works great and the phone quickly loads websites/images, so no complaints here. Motorola has really kept it mostly pure and there is no bloatware. There is a feature that allows you to peek at notifications from the lock screen with a long press. I find that the Moto Assistant is pretty useful and it automatically silences my phone when I'm a meeting since it knows what my Google Calendar events are. See pics for more details about Moto's additional features. CONS When I first got it, the default messaging app was tied into Verizon I think, so I downloaded Google Messenger and set that as my default SMS app. My only other gripe is the low camera quality, but that is to be expected for something that costs about $40. The pictures are more "grainy" compared to my S4. DURABILITY I have dropped this phone several times without a case and it is fine - no cracks or damages. OVERALL, a great,cheap phone for casual users that don't need high-quality pictures. This is a perfect phone for younger children or people who want a basic smartphone and don't care too much about the camera quality.

reviews.name: Mitch E
reviews.body: I bought this phone is September of 2015 for my dad who is just getting into smartphones and he loves it! The phone itself is not anything compared to $400+ phone, but for $50, it is a steal. The software is great and runs really fast. The construction is nice, solid-feeling and fairly grippy. The battery seems to last my dad all day with low to moderate use. The included micro SD card slot is also a nice addition. The only bad things I'd say about this phone is that the screen is less than 720p, which as a person who has used a 2k phone, is very poor to my eyes. Also, the camera is 5mp, which looks quite bad, but again, this is a $50 phone, so many corners will be cut to meet that sale price. Pros: Battery lasts all day Construction is great Included Micro SD card slot Cons: Poor screen resolution(>720p) Poor photo quality (5mp back; VGA front) Conclusion: This phone is great for any new phone user looking for a good phone for the cheapest price.

reviews.name: FlyBoy
reviews.title_review: Convenient Verizon Lollipop 5.1 Phone, Mediocre Voice Quality.
reviews.body: I just got this Moto E and set it up. I haven't updated to Lollipop 5.1 yet, but the update is downloaded and ready to go. It is convenient and responsive, decent screen quality, and fits my hand and pocket well. My biggest complaint with this phone is it has a somewhat grainy voice quality which is reminiscent of digital phones when they first came out. I am comparing to an 3-year-old Droid Razr Maxx and a new Samsung Note 4, both of which are much better. The speaker also has a tinny sound quality. It also does not have a flash for the camera. I am replacing an older Verizon phone on a post-paid plan. This is a pre-paid phone, but it is not locked to pre-paid. I turned it on for an initial test, then turned it off before it could start the setup. It wanted me to register for a new pre-paid plan. I popped the rear bezel off with a finger nail and removed the sim card that came with the phone. I inserted the post-paid sim from my old phone and turned the phone back on. It immediately recognized the sim and displayed my existing post-paid phone number. After I completed the setup I was able to make calls and send text messages. I noticed the download arrow in the notification area. It was downloading a lot of old apps from my other phone, so I had to immediately log onto Google Play and press "Stop" to stop the phone from downloading. I wish there was a way to delete apps from Google Play using a computer as using the phone is slow and tedious. Plus I have these apps on two other phones, and I may have to delete them from each phone before they go away and stop trying to download. Other than that, I'm good to go!!!

reviews.name: Amazon Customer
reviews.body: Great little phone works really well. Broke my on contract phone at Verizon so this is doing fill-in duty till the other is paid for. I know its a prepaid phone but if you pay one month of service they will convert it to a regular verizon phone and add it to your account...don't tell anybody ;) . It has been working flawlessly for me. Camera is so so but the phone is way better than the purchase price.

reviews.name: A. Lewis
reviews.title_review: Such a good deal for the price!
reviews.body: I got this phone to try android and was very impressed with the features for the price! As an employee of Apple, I've always had iPhones, but was wanting to try an android because of boredom. This was a very cheap option with lots of features. Pros: Very strong build quality. Doesn't feel cheap like the Samsungs I've tried. The rubberized curved back made it easy to hold on to without a case. The reception seemed just as good as my iPhone's I've had. LTE was quick. The processor seemed to be on par with the iPhone 5 of a few years ago according to benchmarks, and was snappy enough for every day use. The non-cluttered version of android was nice and probably helped with performance. Still was able to load clash of clans and even real racing 3 in reasonable times. Graphics of course didn't seem on par with iPhone or more expensive android devices, but I didn't expect that. I was able to load in my SIM card from my regular contracted line with an adapter since it was a nano sim, and it activated with no issues. Cons: The reason I didn't subtract any stars for these was because it was $50! Even at the normal unlocked price at $100, it's still a good deal. Most of my complaints are OS related and not because of the phone itself. Motorola has been doing quite well at making quality devices for good prices the last couple years (see the new Moto X!). If I wasn't so invested in the Apple ecosystem, I'd probably switch. The camera quality was awful, but I expected that from a 5 mp camera with no flash. So unless there's good lighting, don't expect to be the most popular person on Instagram. The screen size was good, but it wouldn't have hurt to put a 720p screen on like the previous year's Moto G. It is very low resolution, but again, it was $50. Just don't expect HD video quality. THE MAIN ISSUE I ran into was because Android Lollipop doesn't allow you to install apps straight to the SD card. So even though you spend money on a large SD card to make up for only having 4gb available because of the OS taking up half the storage, you still end up running out of space because it can't download updates anymore if you have a lot of apps. I tried everything in moving all the apps possible to the SD, but it still downloads the updates to the main drive before transferring them. I gave up trying to have any large games on it more than 1 gb. Overall, it was a good temporary device, but I didn't keep it since it wasn't functional enough to take complete advantage of the extra storage you add.

reviews.name: Jenise
reviews.body: I've had this phone now for about 6 months and I love it! I know some people have had issues with the sound or hearing people when they are called, but I haven't had this problem at all. I have trouble activating it, so I had to take it to a Verizon store and they were able to get it working. If you like using your phone as an MP3 player or you like to download a lot of app, you may want to buy a larger memory card.

reviews.name: Xoom
reviews.body: Very very impressed with it. I bought it for my daughter and it's a million times better than my HTC phone! It has a built-in radio transmitter which is very cool. It's a good phone and I would recommend it for others.

reviews.name: Jake
reviews.body: While this phone can leave some to be desired if approached with the wrong attitude, it not only gets the job done but has impressed me several times. As a iPhone user since the iPhone 3, I purchased this product to essential try the Android ecosystem without breaking the bank. While the Android software is bloated down fairly heavily with this phone, especially considering the very limited internal storage size and storage management system with an SD card (only some/few apps being able to be moved to the SD card and the whole experience of moving those apps to be cumbersome and frustrating), the bloatware is not as bad as it could be. The phone starts at roughly 8 GB and with the android OS taking up 3 GB, you're left with 5 GB which sounds decent but shrinks very fast with the size of current applications and the data that they hold. That being said, this phone runs impressively smooth and certainly usable even under load of switching between several apps. The phone isn't as snappy as say the iPhone 6 (the only phone I have to compare it to) but rightfully so given the incredible price-point of the Moto E compared to a number of other phone and certainly compared to any iPhone. The buttons don't feel as insuring as the snappiness of the device, however, being somewhat loose and responsive enough to get the job done but definitely lacking a satisfying feeling when going to make a button press. The screen is by no means impressive, but it's also not disappointing. It leaves a little to be desired but is sharp enough that things are still somewhat crisp. Another important thing to note (that I wasn't aware of at the time that I purchased this device but soon found is one of the larger disappointments I had in the device) is that the Verizon pre-paid version of this phone cannot be rooted or unlocked to flash a custom ROM. While this certainly isn't a deal-breaker, especially for the people that don't have the technical skill or the ones that are not interesting in the perks of rooting or flashing, being able to root or unlock the phone would add to the value tremendously as it could eliminate the small drawbacks that I did find I had including the storage management, bloatware, and few other odd twerks with settings. The Verizon pre-paid version is one of the only versions of this phone that is carrier locked by my understanding and isn't unlock-able so some research and possibly look into the Sprint or other model/versions of this phone is advised if you wish to take advantage of those things. With all things considered, especially including the absolute steal of a price, this phone is pretty superb for its bracket. It definitely isn't a flagship, but it wasn't designed to be and with that in mind, it is certainly impressive and exceeds expectations in several aspects.

reviews.name: Dat's Me
reviews.body: I bought this phone to switch carriers and hopefully to have service in a remote area, controlled by a CDMA carrier that owns most of the transmission towers in that area. (NOT the carrier listed on the phone and I also own a "1 st" generation of the same phone for GSM use, now.) So far, I have only transferred my information, screen configuration and contact list to the new phone and haven't activated the phone with the new carrier I have chosen. (Why? I have "some" minutes to use with my current carrier, before porting my number.) SO--- if you are interested, check back later, 3 - 6 months or so, after I activate the phone and discover if it works, A- with my new chosen carrier and B- in the remote area where I need a phone. (Please note, that if it does not work for either purpose, I can also use it in my normal day to day calling, as a back-up, so I am good to go either way.)

reviews.name: William C. Opie
reviews.title_review: Great, Cheap Replacement Phone for Post-Paid Verizon Customers
reviews.body: I picked up this phone for $44.99, which is insanely cheap for a decent Android phone off-contract. The description says that the phone is Verizon pre-paid only-- but that's not true! I put my post-paid SIM card in the phone before turning the phone on for the first time, and it worked without any issues. I bought this phone as a replacement for my current device (this was $100 cheaper than paying for a replacement phone through Assurion). I would recommend this phone for anyone who needs a replacement phone to get them by for a few months until their contract is up for renewal. It's not a top-end phone by any means, but it works well and I'm not missing my old HTC One Max (a phone with far superior hardware). This phone is also running Android 5.0 out-of-the-box. For this price, you're not going to find a better phone-- whether this is a replacement OR your primary phone. [Additionally, you can find ways to use this phone with other carriers (like T-Mobile, ATT, Sprint, etc.) on the XDA-Developers forum. You have to do a little bit of work, but it's definitely worth for the versatility of being able to drop in a SIM card from any carrier.]

reviews.name: Gregory Schipf
reviews.title_review: A solid android phone for the cost of an iphone case.
reviews.body: I have an iPhone 6 provided from my job but I like to keep my personal phone separate from work. I wanted something on Verizon prepaid and I didn't want to spend a lot. I have to say, I'm really impressed by the moto e. My last phones have been the galaxy s5, the iPhone 5 and the iPhone 6. All great phones, but really, at $500-$600 new, they really ought to be. First off, its been awhile since I have experienced android and I have to say it's come a long way. If you are a heavy google user, (maps,chrome, gmail etc) it really is a no brainer to have an android phone. The apple versions of these apps work, but just not as seemlessly and effortlessly. All that aside, this is a $47 phone I'm reviewing. The fact that I use my iPhone 6 next to this and its not awful says it all. Its fast enough for regular use, it loads everything quickly , build quality is pretty standard and solid, battery lasts all day. The places this phone falls short are screen resolution and camera quality. The screen resolution is noticeable against an iPhone but I was less bothered by it than I thought I would be. The camera is probably the only reason I could see myself ever needing more phone than this. That said, if makes me feel more inclined to take pics with my real camera which blows my iPhone away, so maybe not the worst thing. All said I can't say enough about how much I like this phone at this price point. I mean, the case I bought for my iPhone cost me $10 less than this entire phone. Its liberating to know its not the end of the world if something happens to it. Last but not least, I bought a 32gig SD card ( the max the moto e can handle) and increased my storage to 40 gigs for $13. Those constant messages about my storage running low on my iPhone 6 sting just a little bit more these days. Not a perfect phone, but at $47 brand new, if this isn't 5 stars, what is?

reviews.name: Scope99
reviews.title_review: You Don't Need a Verizon Plan At All!!!
reviews.body: This is much better than most of the prepaid phones on the market that you may want to use. I simply let it charge for only 15 minutes to look at the wifi capabilities but it might be better to not turn on the phone at all before you insert a SIM card from a BYOP tracfone program or another carrier. It is really simple if you follow the directions in the tracfone Bring Your Own Phone activation kit and you are good to go. I also did not have any problems at all and my minutes transferred from my old account to the new cell phone within fifteen minutes. Tracfone has much better prices than verizon so I would use the other SIM card kit for the phone and it is totally wrong that it has to be used on the Verizon plan. The only thing that shows now is the Verizon Wireless text in odd places but it just flashes and then goes off quickly. It does not even say "SIM Card is missing," after you turn it off several times and I only disabled the Verizon App and then the SIM Card Toolkit App and it was good to go. I thought I would have to learn some kind of cell phone command language or order an unlock code, but I barely did anything but activate my new SIM card very quickly lol. Updated Review 3 Months After Purchase: For some customers, they might want to add a second user to the phone that lets you have an entire different screen and set of apps. So technically I don't think it lets you add a new user if you did not use Verizon. I have been trying for an hour to download an app on a New User account or even the guest account and it keeps saying there is a connectivity problem that is strange and also does not appear on my regular account. Even more concerning, the account for the new user and the guest also are freezing out of control and have to "Check connection" for five minutes every time you try to log in. Sadly this is very unusual for the phone and I believe it is because it tries to look for the Verizon account setup. I think it is overall as the original user much better than an iPhone 4s that has been used for a year for speed, screen size and overall color, and even the phone response to the touch even though I had a life proof cover on the iPhone for the entire span of it and it has never been dropped or cracked. So the original user interface is really wonderful but in comparison the option to add a new user or a guest user is hacked if you are using another network.

reviews.name: OldRaschal
reviews.body: From the word go this phone was a pain.

reviews.name: Piaw Na
reviews.title_review: Does everything much more expensive phones do at an amazingly low costs.
reviews.body: I have to say that over the last year or so, Android has finally redeemed itself in my eyes, and the reason for that mostly has to do with Motorola. The Moto G has been an unmitigated top level experience for me so far, so when I found $10 Moto E LTE (Verizon) being blown out by Best Buy during Black Friday, I picked up one. In previous years, you would have been hard pressed to recommend an Android phone for anything under $200. In fact, for my parents, I'd moved them to Lumia phones for that reason: it seemed that for anything with under 2GB of RAM, Android was really sluggish, and had miserable battery life. The Motorola Moto E with 1GB of RAM didn't seem like it would be any better, but for $10 I could have a spare phone. I'm a T-mobile user, so the first thing I did was to follow the instructions to convert the phone to GSM mode. These instructions involved turning the phone into a developer machine, and then using adb to set the wireless radios to talk to the GSM network instead. The penalty is that if you ever switch SIMs (or even pull the SIM out and reboot), the device will revert back into Verizon mode, so this isn't a phone you could expect to travel to various countries and buy local SIM cards with: you'd have to go through the unlock sequence every time you inserted a new SIM card into the device, so unless you're also bringing a laptop with adb installed and are willing to go through it every time you switch SIMs, you're better off buying a truly unlocked phone. Part of the reason Android performance on lower end devices is now acceptable is because hardware has gotten faster. The Moto E LTE has a Snapdragon 410 SoC, which is clocked just 200MHz slower than the one in the Moto G 2015. That 15% disadvantage in clock speed is noticeable, but it's the 1GB of RAM that's really what makes the phone feel less than instantly responsive to your touch. Apps startup just that bit slower, though once started, the apps feel just as fast as on the Moto G. Note, however, that app startup is something you do frequently on Android phones: you click on a link in Gmail, for instance, and startup a web browser. You'd click the share button on the web browser, and then bring up Facebook or Google+ to post. So the performance penalty for task switching really hurts if you're a power user. The camera is decent for taking pictures of receipts and in good light. But without even a flash to help, it's pretty much something you're not going to use and be delighted with. The 4.5" screen feels like a throwback to 5 years ago: coming from the Moto G, you wonder how anyone ever thought 4.7" was a decently sized phone, let alone 4.5". The smaller screen does help with the performance, though: with fewer pixels to push, the device is acceptably fast most of the time. For $10, the phone is definitely a deal. It's more than acceptable, and better than any of the cheap Lumias from past years. For the full retail price of $120, I'd say the Windows Phones start looking better. Fortunately, you'd never have to pay that: the Amazon street price of the phone is around $35, and at that price, I'm think that Windows Phones aren't ever going to be taking market share from Android. The Moto E LTE is a phone that does everything that the higher end devices do acceptably, and with the full range of apps that the windows phones cannot match. I'm now convinced that even supposedly "thin" skins such as found on the Sony Xperia phones suck a ton of CPU/GPU power away from UI responsiveness, and that's to be avoided if at all possible, and if you manage to do so, phone hardware is now powerful enough that the Windows phones no longer have an advantage. Recommended. I have to say, if Motorola had been smart enough to make the Moto X Pure waterproof, it would now be in the running for an upgrade: that's how impressive the Moto G has been. Seriously, I have no idea why most of the flagship phones aren't waterproof. It seems like such a basic feature if even a $180 phone can achieve it!

reviews.name: Chase Adams
reviews.title_review: A high end phone from 4 years ago for a fraction of the price
reviews.body: Here is all the smartphone a normal person needs at a very attractive price. I've had a smartphone since the original iPhone S because I am a business user and viewing the internet on the go was a godsend. My litmus test for a phone was and still is whether it works well... its quick, has all the features, etcetera. I don't buy phones as jewelry ... they are tools. I only buy expensive tools if they make sense, and I don't see the advantage to buying an expensive phone if a lower priced phone works for my needs. Two years ago I bought one of the first android phones to reach the $100, and it was a completely different story than this Moto E. It was slow and ran out of memory all the time. It was almost unusable. I ended up replacing it quickly, but I knew the time would come where good phones would drop below that price, and apparently the time is now. Two months ago I bought this phone. Simply put, it is great. Its fast and completely usable for all of my smartphone needs. The battery lasts all day. The case is sturdy and the screen is similar to a high end phone from 2 or 3 years ago. Here is a great personal pocket computer for the price of a dinner for two. The one part of the phone I'm not satisfied with are the cameras. They're okay, but better cameras are what I'll look forward to from an upgrade in the future. For the price, I'm blown away by the value.

reviews.name: Travis Pham
reviews.title_review: Best Budget Android Phone That Can Be Used On ANY CARRIER
reviews.body: I had this for about over a year now and for all you wondering it WILL work on any gsm carrier. You do need to do some things on your computer to unlock it but it was for free. I will post the article below. I love this phone because i bought it for $10 during black Friday last year. Since then it has been a reliable phone for me. It does slow down here and there but it quickly goes back on its feet and does what you want it to do Pros: reliable fast if you dont have any apps running battery lasts a day for a somewhat heavy user can be used on any gsm carrier Cons laggs a bit Speaker not loud enough charging takes 3+ hours on stock charger but 2 hours with faster charger

reviews.name: B. Contor
reviews.title_review: Great to use as an MP3 player for a collection of old converted cassette tapes and ripped CDs. Haven't tried it as a phone.
reviews.body: I bought this specifically to use as an MP3 player and it is GREAT. I haven't activated phone service so I can't speak to that. I have battled with an iPod Touch and iPad for six years and iTunes is so intuitive I have never figured it out. In less than 72 hours and under $70 total (Moto E, 16 gigabyte micro SD card, and $3.99 paid version of PowerAmp app) I have accomplished what I could never figure out in Appledom: I have imported three flavors of music from a Windows PC: a) iTunes purchases over the Internet; b) Ripped CDs; c) Ancient MP3 files generated from old cassette tapes I owned, using PolderBits software (that was years ago, don't know if it is still available), and organized Playlists based on the file structure from the PC. What Appledom could never never do was recognize the folder structure. So tape A was in a nice little folder with its name and songs labeled "Track_01" etc. Tape B was in its little folder with songs labeled "Track_01" etc. All the Apple's horses and all the Apple's men could never keep it straight and I always had all the "Track_01" jammed together, followed by all the "Track_02," etc. I could manually sort it out but heaven forbid I should sync the iPod again, or update iTunes! With PowerAmp, I can scroll by folders AND THEY ARE THE WAY I ORGANIZED THEM ON THE PC! What a novel concept! Who would ever have thought a person would want the same organization on their MP3 player as on the PC! There are some odd artifacts; mainstream commercial CDs are OK for the most part, but some high school choir CDs and Pimsleur language CDs have odd embedded data which may have come from ripping with iTunes, or from somewhere else. These are all in their own files where I stored them, as near as I can tell, but in the "folder" view it seems I can also see them in ghost folders based on whatever is in the hidden attributes. Some of the high school songs are attributed to random commercial artists, and some Pimsleur language files are co-mingled across languages. But I still can go to the original folder from PC and EVERYTHING IS WHERE I PUT IT; the co-mingling is only in the ghost folders. Once the files are loaded, PowerAmp seems a little harder to use than the Apple player - more options, more chances to go wrong. It took me a while to get it to stick to one playlist. There are shuffle options that will jump from list to list and I'm pretty sure I don't understand all I know about it. I haven't yet figured out how to make it display which playlist I'm listening to. I hope I can, that was something I liked about the iPod. Back to the phone itself, I do notice that the cover art is not as crisp on this phone as on the iPhone, but I don't listen with my eyes. If you are buying the phone as a phone and the display is important to you, this is a step down from an expensive phone. However even with my trifocals I can read all the text I need for navigating through my music. The speaker on the phone is pretty good - better than my old iPod Touch and at least as good as my company-issued iPhone 6 - and it sounds great to me plugged into my desktop speakers. But I don't pretend to be an audiophile. I'm not saying anything bad about the sound, I'm saying I don't have the ear to tell. It is loud enough to listen to talk recordings riding around in my pocket while I do chores. I haven't tried it with headphones. The FM radio tuner is decent but it only works when something is plugged into the headphone jack; the cable is the antenna. I have played with the Internet over WiFi a little. When I'm doing one thing at a time it seems every bit as fast as the iPhone 6, on the same WiFi signal. I haven't activated the phone service so I don't know how it would be accessing the Web over a cell signal. Also I have not tried browsing the Web with other apps running in the background. After spending an hour or more organizing playlists, and playing external speakers for 7 hours and the built in speaker for another couple of hours, the battery indicator looks like it is still about 2/3 full. The first day it seemed to drain faster but after a long overnight charge it is working great.

reviews.name: Pokerbluff
reviews.body: I ended up reading the one star reviews. I think they are all fake. The phone does work for me though. I had a nexus 6 but it ran too hot. This runs the same temperatures but does not bother me. It is smaller and easy to carry. I have put a lot of system updates on it and it is very fast. It does everything well. The cheap price is nice as you do not have to worry as much about robbery, breaking, etc. It is slow to charge but many fast charging phones get hot so I just deal with it. I did add 32gb of memory. Only some apps install on the sd card and you have to move then to it. It has a hidden menu that you can see with network app and use this on GSM networks, But I have not tried it. So, I can not say it works. The camera is ok. It is not really all that great but it is ok. The second camera is weak but it is ok for this price. The android phone has a big advantage over windows phones and works very nice. The only bad thing is that it is 2.4gz only on wifi. It does not do 5gz.
